doc/source/open-infrastructure.rst.message: Repetition of overloaded terms "infrastructure" and "project" make this a little confusing, might be clearer to say "The OpenDev sysadmins strive to run the services behind the OpenDev Collaboratory as..."
Done
Or maybe just "...to contribute to OpenDev."

I get that it is a general point that you don't need permissions to contribute to any of OpenDev, but I think I like this as is because it's specifically calling out that you can contribute to the services back-end, which I think is very unique.
We've been terming the infrastructure team "OpenDev sysadmins" since the dissolution of the OpenStack Infrastructure project.
Done

There are lots of occurrences of terms surrounded by single backticks, which Sphinx seems to be converting to italics similar to terms surrounded by asterisks, but the former isn't called out in the Sphinx or reST docs as standard markup.
hrm, i mean <tt>; i'll correct this to ``.  I think it's markdown that renders `code`
Gerrit will also accept https://review.opendev.org/q/project:opendev/system-config which might be a bit more user-friendly since we're displaying a raw URL here.
Done
Stray "." here.
Done
Might be more precise to say "nested Ansible" since the Ansible executed by Zuul is not represented there.
done, I made it *nested* Ansible to emphasise it's difference.
unit-test-like
Done
Elsewhere you're including a trailing "/" on git_file references to directories. I think I prefer that as it makes it clear we're referring to a directory rather than a single file.
Done

Should we choose a different term than "secrets" in order to avoid confusion with configured Zuul secrets (which these aren't)? Maybe "private data," "sensitive values," or something along those lines?
I couldn't find another term that seemed more logical than *secrets*.  But I reworded the whole thing to make it clearer it's coming from values stored on the bastion host

We might want to refer to these as "pipelines" rather than "queues" for alignment with Zuul's terminology (which has queues within the pipelines, but the names you're providing are the pipeline names not the queue names).
Good idea, changed.
Nit we call it "deploy" in zuul.
Done
Wound it make sense to say that it's triggered "to run a nested Ansible" for clarity?
Yes, reworded this.
"leak sensitive information" (aside from possible confusion with Zuul secrets, they could leak other sensitive information beyond what you referred to as "secrets" earlier)
Done
should add a trailing "/"
Done
Could say "two geographically distinct locations" even, which is the most important aspect.
Done
It seems like the number of blank lines between sections is entirely random. Sometimes one, sometimes two, in this case we have three?
All are now one 😊
Missing a trailing "/" here.
Done
While I completely agree with this paragraph, it seems somewhat out of place in the Documentation section. Should we have a separate section about our expectations for commit messages?
Added a section, and linked to some of the developer guides for getting setup before this paragraph.

Since you named the link "weekly team meeting" it may make more sense to link to https://meetings.opendev.org/#OpenDev_Meeting rather than the agenda in the wiki. Otherwise include Agenda in the link name instead. Also you don't need a double-underscore for this sort of link, a single trailing underscore is typical.
Added links to the meetings.opendev.org section as well, can clarified that's the agenda.
Which IRC channels? Might make more sense to specify one, especially since this is the first and only mention of IRC on this page.
Added that.  I also added a sentence with a link to service-discuss as another channel for help
Gerrit is a proper noun, so should be capitalized as you've done elsewhere in the document.
Done
Should we also mention Workflow -1 here?
Done
Nit: Trailing underscores for named links like this one don't need to be doubled, a single underscore there is sufficient and more typical (but it still renders fine either way).

tacker/conductor/conductor_server.py.message: What is the reason of allowing non-LccnSubscriptionRequest object?

The method "__set_auth_subscription" is called in two places.
If the method "test_notification" calls it, the input parameter is LccnSubscriptionRequest, which is entered from a user command.
If the method "send_notification" calls it, the input parameter is LccnSubscription, which is taken from the database.

The method 'test_notification' is not a test code,it is called when an user regists a subscription for a notification.
When subscribing to notifications, this function is used to ensure that notifications can be sent normally.The registing subscription can only succeed if the test_notification method returns the correct results.
Do I need to add the TODO comment?

Sorry, I misunderstood.

Another problem is that else block will accept any ``vnf_lcm_subscription`` objects which have the ``authentication`` attribute.
Ideally, only LccnSubscription or LccnSubscriptionRequest should be accepted*1, but I suppose ``vnf_lcm_subscription`` passed from "send_notification" is not a LccnSubscription class. Am I correct? c.f., [1]. If so, please add TODO comment like: "Only LccnSubscription or LccnSubscriptionRequest should be accepted."

\*1
```
        if not isinstance(vnf_lcm_subscription, LccnSubscriptionRequest) and not isinstance(vnf_lcm_subscription, LccnSubscription):
            # raise Exception

        if ('authentication' not in vnf_lcm_subscription or
                not vnf_lcm_subscription.authentication):
            return
```

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/tacker/objects/vnf_lcm_subscriptions.py#L104-L158

Sorry, the previous comment was incorrect.Through actual environmental testing, it was found that the type of vnf_lcm_subscription was sqlalchemy.engine.row.LegacyRow, not LcnSubscription.

Considering that the type of the mock object passed in from the existing unit test code is DummyLcmSubscription, the processing logic is not added. Only added the TODO comment.

# TODO(YiFeng) The type of vnf_lcm_subscription should be
#  LegacyRow or LccnSubscriptionRequest,
#  else should raise an exception

I understand. Adding logic that depends on test codes is not a good thing, so we should fix it later. Please add a TODO comment.
```
TODO: Fix test cases depending on this else block
```

Good! thanks.

Frankly, using LegacyRow directly is not a good habit, but we can fix it in the future.

Could you please fix here quickly?
According to SOL013 [1] it should be
```
        if 'BASIC' in authentication['auth_type']:
            auth_type = 'BASIC'
            auth_params = authentication['param_basic']
        elif 'OAUTH2_CLIENT_CREDENTIALS' in authentication['auth_type']:
            auth_type = 'OAUTH2_CLIENT_CREDENTIALS'
            auth_params = authentication['params_oauth2_client_credentials']
        else:
            error = 'Unknown auth_type %s' % authentication['auth_type']
            raise exceptions.TackerException(error)  # please replace TackerException with an appropriate exception  
```

If the existing codes raise errors, please leave these lines and add a ``TODO`` comment.

[1] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/013/03.03.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL013v030301p.pdf#page=32
The code block is the existing logic and has been modified with reference to the above comments.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'm not sure the co-relation being made between a mandatory field and it not having a default value.

I think my comment was regarding the client code where the control_location field is optional and a default value is provided.
You're correct with respect to cinder API.
I think we need to fix the gap between client and API here.
I think "default value" means if a parameter is not passed, it will take the "default value", so for a mandatory field, we must pass the parameter in, which makes "default value" useless.
Please avoid linking to github in commit messages.  The Cinder project isn't hosted on github.

It would be a bit more informative to say:

control_location has been required in the POST /v3/{uid}/types/{tid}/encryption request body since schema validation was introduced in rocky.  Update the api-ref text to be accurate.
This patch doesn't seem relevant to that blueprint.  (I think it's a bug you discovered while working on the BP?)

:-1: As far as I understood we need to add:
Closes-Bug: #1964145
Ignore this. That bug needs a new patch.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Couldn't the fact that this value is required, despite it may just use a default value, be considered as a bug and fixed in the code instead?

We discussed this at the cinder bug squad meeting today and concluded that instead of changing the api-ref, we'll change the code to do what the docs currently say.  This is backward compatible and won't require a new microversion because it's a widening change, that is, all requests that previously succeeded will continue to succeed when the "optional" control_location is included in the request.

Yes, I think this is a good idea -- "front-end" is used almost all of the time, we should just default to this.

Filed this as a bug:
    https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1964145

api-ref/source/v3/parameters.yaml.message: There's no default value here, either.  If the control_location is included, the schema forces the user to pick one of the values from the enum.  (Same thing for v2)

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
Sorry if my question is too obvious but why do we need to set the signature of the wrapper? I can't find this use in any part of the code to use as a reference. I guess it's because backward compatibility but If you have more info to add, please let me know. 
https://docs.python.org/3/library/inspect.html#inspect.signature

I'm still not 100% sure why it is done this way and not with functools.wraps
This does preserve the signature but not the name (f.__name__) or docstring (f.__doc__) of the wrapped method which are lost. functools handles all properties of the original method so again why are we doing it like this?
Ack! Thanks Brian! The patch looks good. @stephenfin: please add more context on the commit msg next time.

This is from PEP-362.  Basically, what's going on is that if we use inspect.signature() on this thing, we want it to give us the signature of the wrapped function, not the signature of the wrapper.

The other functions in this file that use the '@functools.wraps' decorator don't get a __signature__ set on them manually by us (or by functools), but functools.update_wrapper() (which is applied by the decorator) does set enough other attributes on them so that when you call inspect.signature(), the correct signature is returned.

You're correct that we don't currently have any tests that take advantage of this, so this is basically future-proofing to save someone time later when they use inspect and find that some stuff is working as expected and some isn't.

kubernetes/k8s-pods-signal-sender/centos.message: on our system "sh" is just a symlink to bash, so may as well make it a bash script

I don't think this syntax is correct.

If we use "xargs crictl stop --timeout 1" then xargs will call crictl once with all of the container IDs.  This is probably what we want.

If we use "xargs -I {} crictl stop --timeout 1 {}" then xargs will call crictl once for each container ID, which may take longer.

Also, is a timeout of 1 long enough?  Maybe be a little more generous, like 5 sec.

Rather than adding a specific service should we not just update kubeadm.conf and either add another 

 ExecStopPost=/usr/local/sbin/k8s-pods-signal-sender

or augment the existing

 ExecStopPost=/bin/rm -f /var/run/kubelet.pid;/usr/local/sbin/k8s-pods-signal-sender

Yes. based on this statement: "This service will be run after kubelet is
stopped at shutdown and will kill all the remaining pods properly."

You just need to make the script smart enough to execute the stop when the system is shutting down. We do the following to unmount RBD devices cleanly on shutdown

https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/ceph/ceph/files/ceph-preshutdown.sh#L13
are you proposing to run this script as an another step when k8s stops?

This is a bit tricky.  This says we want the k8s-pods-signal-sender service to be *started up* after kubelet.service.  But according to the systemd docs, on shutdown the reverse order is applied, meaning that we would shut down this service first before shutting down kubelet.service.

However, the docs also say "Given two units with any ordering dependency between them, if one unit is shut down and the other is started up, the shutdown is ordered before the start-up. It doesn't matter if the ordering dependency is After= or Before=, in this case. It also doesn't matter which of the two is shut down, as long as one is shut down and the other is started up; the shutdown is ordered before the start-up in all cases."

So I *think* it might be okay, but it's probably worth explicitly verifying that the ordering is correct, and adding a comment in this file explaining what's going on.
I don't think we're starting it here, are we?

We discussed this at the 9 March cinder meeting, and adopted this policy (which is taken directly from the oslo.i18n guidelines [0]):

  _() is preferred for any user facing message, even if it is also going to a log file. This ensures that the translated version of the message will be available to the user.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.i18n/latest/user/guidelines.html

cinder/volume/drivers/huawei/huawei_conf.message: Isn't this too late to do the strip()?  If text is '  5  ', you're going to take the branch at line 425 and raise InvalidInput and will never reach this line.

thanks you,you're right.this is redundant
i fix it
ints have unlimited precision, so this is not a good way to determine that the text passed to int() is too large.

i think this restriction is superfluous as well
i fix it
I think this would be better as 'using'.  (The difference is that your message is reporting something that the code is doing, vs. telling the operator that they should be doing something.)
Log messages should not be translated with _(). Also, no need to define the msg variable, just put the text right in the LOG.info() call.

i change to LOG.info("MinOnlineFCInitiator not set, using default.") ?
define the msg variable I want to keep the same style as before.

Same.

And then change `text` to be passed in as an argument in the LOG.error call so the logger can take care of the string formatting.

i change like this:
   msg = (_("Invalid FC MinOnlineFCInitiator '%s',MinOnlineFCInitiator must be a digit.") % text)
   LOG.error((_("Invalid FC MinOnlineFCInitiator '%s',MinOnlineFCInitiator must be a digit.") , text))
   raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg)
But I wonder if it's not necessary？

Thanks for changing this, but I think it's still not correct.  We don't mark log messages for translation because operators have asked that they be logged in US-English to make them easier to find in web searches.

So what you need to do here is in 2 stages:

        if not text.isdigit():
            LOG.error("Invalid FC MinOnlineFCInitiator '%s', "
                      "MinOnlineFCInitiator must be a digit.", text)
            msg = (_("Invalid FC MinOnlineFCInitiator '%s', "
                     "MinOnlineFCInitiator must be a digit.") % text)
            raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg)

(Repeating the string is non-optimal, but you need to pass a string literal to the _() function.)

Here's the translation docs:
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.i18n/latest/user/guidelines.html

That being said, the translate-log-raise pattern is used all over the place in this file (and probably in cinder in general), so I'm not sure whether we want to require this or not.  Or I could be completely misreading the guidelines in the translations docs ... look them over and see what you think.

Yeah, ideally we would separate them out so the log message is not localized, but the exception returned is. I think we've been pretty lax about this in the past though. There are likely a ton of places in the code that are just using the same string for both logging and exception messages.

Not sure how strict we want to be about that. My personal opinion is that, at least for this particular instance, the string contains enough non-localizable words that it doesn't really make that much of a difference. I am more concerned about applying localization to the strings that are only going to the log and creating unnecessary work for the translators.

For future's reference could you please point to where it is in pyrout2, to make life easier if it is changed again?
I tried to find it but I am always lost in pyrout2 code, and perhaps somehwere here it is written as docstring/comment:
https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/netlink/__init__.py#L981-L983

But perhaps there's some higher level place where it is visible/written
thanks, I feared it will be something like this :/

This is not explicitly said in the code. That depends on how the "iproute" structures are built. When calling the "iproute" library, Pyroute2 builds the IFLA_VF_RATE structure that must be [1], and decoded in [2].

In Pyroute2, the structures are built depending on the parameter names. When passing "vf" and inside "rate", that will call [3].

If any of those keys (min_tx_rate, max_tx_rate) is not set, Pyroute2 will assign a 0 value. For example:
  $ from neutron.plugins.ml2.drivers.mech_sriov.agent import pci_lib
    pci=pci_lib.PciDeviceIPWrapper("enp196s0f0")
    pci.set_vf_rate(15, {'max_tx_rate': 10})

This code will generate a "msg" [4] like this: https://paste.opendev.org/show/b2FZBOebGOCHMrYhPr6X/. "msg" is the structure that is passed to the "iproute" library.

I'll update the commit message with this information.

[1]https://github.com/shemminger/iproute2/blob/c8d9d92544668922dc5aa06d2491f42b837b9361/ip/ipaddress.c#L454-L470
[2]https://github.com/shemminger/iproute2/blob/c8d9d92544668922dc5aa06d2491f42b837b9361/ip/iplink.c#L457-L469
[3]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/netlink/rtnl/ifinfmsg/__init__.py#L712-L717
[4]https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/blob/a9564dff8e53659f761d71bbee0dd68dd0db6ce8/pyroute2.core/pr2modules/iproute/linux.py#L1499

tripleo_common/utils/config.py.message:
I think it probably makes the most sense to provide base level pod_config.j2.yaml files and then process the jinja2 here. I know we discussed Kustomize. I'm not sure if we would get benefit from Kustomize since we would still need to render a file with all of our variables before we could use it. 

Otherwise, we could just add them as templates to the related tripleo-ansible change and render them during the deployment into /var/lib/tripleo-config.....

specs/xena/tripleo-next-container-pods.r.message: AFAIK, using jinja for YAML specs is a heavy anti-pattern in Kubernetes universe. If we plan to converge architectures one day, should we try to use kustomize instead of J2 templates? It could be some ephemeral tiny k8s-light pod we start each time to process pod specs via kustomize, for example. Similarly to how we use Heat Ephemeral pod that, with a stretch, resembles a miniature OpenStack deployment :)
https://youtu.be/1fCAwFGX38U?t=367 in particular shows why jinja/parametrization quickly becomes suboptimal

While Jinja may not be "kube-native" I don't think this would be wrong for our use-case; so I both agree and disagree with the sententment. I think adding kustomize would be a heavy anti-pattern within OpenStack, especially considering all the Jinja we use within TripleO, which is our primary concern.

I think generating POD YAML files would be the thing we could share, no matter how we do it. Once we have a set of functional POD files we can begin sharing those generated resources between systems. Our generated set could then be "kustomize'd" within a Kube environment to fit their needs as a secondary use-case.

I can see it both ways, and I will update the spec to indicate some way of customization is needed, and to not assume jinja2.

kustomize is nice because afaict, it is just a go binary, so we could easily use it within tripleo, and I also like the idea of more kube native tooling for both platforms. Meaning, if kustomize is the pattern for kube, then I'd just assume use it with podman as well.
let's mention the podman ansible collection, which is used beneath the tripleo ansible modules. How would that impact supporting it upstream and in tripleo-ansible? Shall we ditch it?
I don't think there would be any developer impact when switching to pods?
yea the collection already has pod support

One thing i think we should pick up is the implementing initContainer support into podman. it'd make our lives 1000 times better if we can move bootstrap stuff into the pods directly.  I know it's mentioned below but I think it'd be a really good thing to have. I'd be willing to push that effort along.
another alternative to podman playkube perhaps is to use static pods and standalone kubelet, which supports initContainers and more things

standalone kubelet is something i have briefly looked into, and afaict no other projects are doing it. There is also no supported and documented kubelet API, it is all considered an internal interface to kubernetes itself.

I don't think standalone kubelet is provided anywhere in the RHEL ecosystem so we'd be on the hook for this. Additionally podman play kube is how you run pods and it doesn't support initContainers today.
I'm not sure it will solve problem of duplicate volumes definitions. Probably we might need "another translator tool" that will optimize pod YAMLs?
nit - wording: "Heat does not have native support for jinja2 rendering"
Done

Just to understand:
- now we have step_*/<service>.json (or yml, or whatever) - would each file represent a pod, or will we group services under the same pod?
- what about pacemaker managed services? Will they also switch to pod, or will they still be "standalone containers"?

yes, it'd be 1 container per pod, unless there is a compelling case to put multiple containers in a pod.

as for the pacemaker managed containers, they would stay managed by pacemaker. You can think of the spec as working to move from docker_config to pod_config. As the pacemaker containers are not specified in docker_config, they would continue to be managed by pacemaker and not podman pods.
Great point. The pattern is to group containers by pods by logical service boundaries. I would say, the same containers we describe in a template today, should stay unchanged in the new pod grouping.
So the intention isn't to create a pod that would have nova-scheduler + nova-conductor for example. These would be seperate pods to stick to the one container per pod method?
corret. initially it would be one container per pod. i added a point to that effect.
Could we use static pod definitions, and rendered configmap files instead? This may make it easier to keep the service definition (the pod) separate from the config definition (the configmap).
Podman doesn't know about configmaps nor static pods, that's the (standalone or in a k8s cluster) kubelet area.
Podman DOES know and supports configmaps with "podman play kube". I think it's very useful for our purpose.
Currently we use systemd files to maintain container persistance. How will we maintain this functionality?
yes
Yes, systemd manages pods exactly in same manner as containers.
The same way, but operating by the pod level abstractions this time, I suppose.

It can be a problem because some of settings are on kubelet level, for example "pids limit"[1] is set on kubelet for node, but in podman it's set for container. We need to identify such cases to see what can be done.

[1] PodPidsLimit in https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/config-api/kubelet-config.v1beta1/#kubelet-config-k8s-io-v1beta1-KubeletConfiguration

I think it also gives users lot of flexibility with things like systemd managed unit per container. Unless we provide something similar user experience would probably not be the same.

Abstractions are good as long as the user/operator experience remains the same or becomes better.
i will update to include covering your concern around abstractions

Why put them THT service templates at all? Those pod yamls (as maintained separately) can be jinja rendered or customized (using other tools like kustomize) with ansible directly the way we do for network config with input values as ansible vars.

the main reason for putting them into tht was just to make get_file work easily. However, it's certainly correct that we don't have to use get_file at all, and just store all the pod YAML separately. I don't like the idea of tripleo-ansible either, because I don't want to make this work more dependent on ansible.

what do you think about in tripleo-common, or a different repo?
Sorry, what I meant by "we already store them separately" is as per the proposed spec we plan to store them separately. I should have phrased it better.
I don't see any uses of get_file with our current container definitions. It's all embedded within docker_config.

We already store them separately and do 'get_file' ('get_file' happens client side) to add to the templates (sent to heat) again. There is no point adding them again to the service templates and increase the service template sizes sent to heat. Just having reference to the location should be enough. It does not matter weather we want to render them using ansible (keeping them in triplo_ansible) or using python and jinja (keeping them in tripleo-common).

IMHO we should evaluate the feasibility of this now before we move to another deployment unit format. Without tripleo pods being scalable units containing related service containers, I don't see lot of value in again changing to a new format.

Also, I would like the spec to cover a little more on the tooling changes for management and troubleshooting (user experience).

the value of a different format is:

- it's not our custom format, but instead one that is well maintained and widely adopted

- can actually be re-used outside of tripleo (k8s/ocp)

- can be used to deploy containers without our heat/ansible automation, even within tripleo (likely for dev/test). e.g., "podman play"

This reminds me of the discussion we had when we wrote paunch (docker-cmd hook in heat) rather than using docker-compose. Also, I wonder if we would be the first few using pods with podman  as I see only very few bugs reported for it[1] (unless it's too good) and ready to be part of another podman adventure.

We ditched several standard formats for our own custom formats earlier (ex. tcib), so I won't be too worried that we're using a custom format. It's been used for several releases and tested well.

Also, as I mentioned earlier, unless we've multiple containers in a pod sharing namespaces/cgroups etc, there is an overhead without any value add.


[1] https://github.com/containers/podman/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Apods

A lot has changed since we moved from paunch to ansible. Such as needing to be looking at ansible alternatives.

Our current custom format is too tightly coupled to Heat/Ansible and doesn't provide for any re-use. At least with paunch, we could have started our containers externally from a full TripleO deploy, but we still needed Heat to generate those container definitions. This proposal will further decouple the definitions away from the service templates as well.
can you please give a more specific link here that is to the root of tht
Done
is
Done
I think we can't move a container into a pod... ? So it will more likely "be stopped, removed and re-created as pods".
also, does that impact dataplane (network connections of workloads)?

Shouldn't impact network connectivity. The vifs are plugged into OvS and OvS is running on the host. We stop and restart containers all the time when configurations change, so it should be the same process and impact that we already have. Just this time when they start back up, we expect they will be defined as pods.

When we update/upgrade a container today, it's a whole new container right? It's not as if you can change the container image and keep the same container from podman's pov. It's a new container id, namespaces, etc. Assuming that is how it works today, I don't see any differences when using pods.

I did a an earlier point that both pod_config and docker_config can co-exist, even in the same service template. That allows for not having to migrate every service to pods at exactly the same time.

That depends, but I'd be pleasantly surprised if there isn't something that will break the dataplane. Neutron sidecar containers are part of the dataplane and we will need to consider how sidecars employed by neutron are impacted. There will be some differences between ML2/OVN and ML2/OVS based deployments due to how much sidecars are used. The sidecars containers are managed by neutron through wrappers, and in the case of ML2/OVS, neutron managed network namespaces are part of how it all works - so probably some thought is required here as well. ML2/OVN is a bit different but we should work out how the OVNController container would be affected.

I we're going ahead with this, as mentioned earlier let's not add content of pod yaml to the service templates using 'get_file', as it would result in unnecessary request playload to heat. Rendering/customization can be done using heat output (inputs) and pod definition(file) by whatever tool we plan to use.

neutron/agent/rpc.py.message: currently it's not async in fact, what if place lines 196-210 here?
I will remove the "async_" prefix, make this to "def _call_update_device_list".

Why 8? Will 16 or 4 do better? My concern is that this number is specific for each environment with specific number of neutron servers/RPC workers, number of nodes/agents and number of ports. I'm afraid not all neutron servers are ready for 8x more calls. Should we catch RPC timeout error and adjust pool size?
Isn't that possible to make it equal with the rpc_worker number?

Isn't it a step back to what we have before https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/638646 ?
I mean agent call device_list in step size chunks, but the calls will arrive simultaneously to neutron-server, so timeout can happen again

The original timeout of 638646 is because the port list is too large. Neutron-server will use to long time to do related processing works. So timeout happens. And one RPC call is go to one rpc-worker. And remember, in real environment there is no one rpc-worker. So, muiltple calls are go to multiple workers. Each RPC worker is still doing small set of works.

The difference is that single 100k call is handled by a single RPC worker - and this may lead to RPC timeout. 12.5K calls are handled by several RPC workers - better chances to avoid timeouts (if have enough RPC workers ready to process calls!)

In any case, Lajos' point is valid. Why this patch we are storming the server with multiple RPC calls that could potentially overload it. So instead of having a single call with 100K elements, you'll have 8 calls with 12,5K elements. In any case, the server will take the same time to reply.

neutron/services/ovn_l3/plugin.py.message:
I don't understand this change. When the port binding is updated, the status of the port doesn't change. The port status is changed before. This port retrieved from the "update_port" method should have the same status as the one retrieved from "get_ports".

As you commented in the LP bug, first you set node A to down. This is when the port changes its status. When the GW port is bound again but to node B (attending PortBindingChassisEvent), this port status is already changed to down.

I don't see how this code was failing before.
Exactly, this what I was looking for. When the port binding is updated, we always set the port status to DOWN and clear the port binding.

This is not what Lucas is saying. What Lucas is stating is that "update_port_status" cannot be called from inside an active transaction. This is because "update_port_status" is calling "update_port_statuses" that has a transaction guard. That means "update_port" and "update_port_status" need to be in two different transactions.

That doesn't explain why the port status retrieved from "get_ports" is different from "update_port".

if we call "update_port" with update binding host, will set port status to down.
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L1827
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/plugin.py#L532

hi rodolfo, you can see lucasagomes‘s notes in L345. if port's device_owner is router_gateway will chagne port status to down.
if port['status'] is active(from L340 get_ports), after update_port(L348) port actual status will be change to down. if we do not update "port['stauts']", will not execute update_port_status and set port status to active.

```
>>> conn.get_aggregate(1)
openstack.compute.v2.aggregate.Aggregate(id=1, name=standalone, hosts=[], metadata={'availability_zone': 'nova'}, deleted=False, availability_zone=nova, location=Munch({'cloud': 'standalone', 'region_name': 'regionOne', 'zone': 'nova', 'project': Munch({'id': 'bdc16c50639c4d3f8383dc76ccb7dd5b', 'name': 'admin', 'domain_id': None, 'domain_name': 'Default'})}))
```

So I'm changing this to replicate what we would expect returned from OSC:
https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/connection.html#openstack.connection.Connection.create_aggregate

OSC get_aggregate returns a dict already. So we don't need to value.to_dict(). We can just create a dictionary and set it as the return value:
https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/connection.html#openstack.connection.Connection.get_aggregate

manifests/controller.pp.message: FYI: Do not use hiera in puppet-octavia but only implement native parameters. If you need this then this should be implemented in tripleo.
We basically avoid defining our own parameter names and just follows the original parameter names.
I prefer not adding this hear and let users to include the class. This enforces ordering of class definition, which makes it difficult to use manifests file to define parameters(instead of hieradata)
Yes. The class should be included in own composition layer and in TripleO's case that should be implemented in puppet-tripleo.
